newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Mahathir confirms leave, Anwar in charge.
newsitem.headline: Mahathir confirms leave, Anwar in charge.

text.p: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad confirmed on Thursday he was going on a two-month trip from the middle of this month, and said his deputy would be fully in charge while he was away.

"Yes I am going on leave. I have never taken my off days in between (work) and I hope I will be allowed to go on leave without much objection," he told reporters on his return from a working visit of African countries.
Malaysian officials said on Wednesday the premier would visit Britain and eastern Europe on a work-and-vacation mission starting on May 19.
News of his leave -- his longest since becoming prime minister in 1981 -- led to much speculation in financial markets on Wednesday.
Dealers said the speculation, centred on the prime minister's health, among other things, led to some weakness in the ringgit. Mahathir had a heart operation eight years ago.
But the 71-year old premier dismissed worries about his health, saying he felt fine, and said he would temporarily hand over his full powers to Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim.
He said there was no need to take any precautionary measures to safeguard the country during his absence, as he had full confidence in Anwar.
Mahathir's decision to go on extended leave has prompted speculation that he might be testing the governing abilities of Anwar, widely regarded as his most natural successor.
